Raja Bhoj: The Scholar King

The Paramara dynasty, which ruled Malwa (Central India), is known for its greatest ruler Raja Bhoj (1010тАУ1055 CE). Bhoj was not only a great conqueror but also a 'Kaviraja' (King of Poets). He wrote 84 books on architecture, medicine, grammar, and yoga, among which 'Samarangana Sutradhara' (Architecture) is famous.

ЁЯПЫя╕П
Dhara and Bhojpur

He made his capital Dhara a center of learning and culture. He built a massive Shiva temple (unfinished) in Bhojpur near Bhopal, which houses one of the world's largest Shivalingas. He also constructed a huge lake (Bhojtal).

тЪФя╕П
Agnikula Rajputs

The origin of the Paramaras is linked to the 'Agnikula' theory (born from fire). They started as feudatories of the Rashtrakutas and became independent under Siyaka II. Constant wars with neighboring kingdoms (Chalukyas, Kalachuris) eventually weakened them. In 1305, Alauddin Khilji's army conquered Malwa.
